It was not just color, but a moment: her in a mirror, adjusting herself before a dinner or a dance, before a life that would fold into memory. I held it to my face and breathed in the scent of time, of a woman who had worn this as both armor and allure. And then, I thought: this is an archive, not of documents, but of breath and blood, of what remains when the body moves on.

Archives are not only places of preservation—they are also of forgetting, of selection, of silence. Derrida called it *archive fever*: the desire to collect, to order, to remember, even as we know all memory is haunted by erasure. We build these graves of paper and fabric and sound, not to resurrect the past, but to dance above it, to step in its rhythm, to feel the tremor of what we cannot hold.
